Name: Adel Bayoumi
Title: Tibet in middle of Delhi
Review: I was not expect to find such a places to visit in Delhi, and if you love Tibetian food then this place is what you looking for.Sure you can buy from these small shope around you, it saves you a trip to Tibet

Name: Anuradha Mukherjee
Title: Overhyped
Review: Overhyped place, congested dirty and a total mess. Went with some expectations but all that it is a narrow street alley with some novelty shops and thats about it. Food isnt great either!

Name: Tester
Title: Great Experience
Review: it was a great experience to visit the Tibetan market out there in majnu ka tilla.Now adding this for the purposes of testing this application

Name: John Doe
Title: Absolutely phenomenon
Review: Great place to taste Tibetan cusine and shop for Tibetan anything. Also a good shopping hub for men and women. Love the atmosphere of this place. It's one of the most awesome place in Delhi to be at.

Name: traveloflight
Title: Friendly Tibetan Colony
Review: I love visiting this area of Delhi.  The rest of Delhi can be exhausting and stressful.  In Majnu Katilla there is a lovely magic and community feel.

Name: SAROJ8585
Title: THE TIBBETIAN CULTURE
Review: Majnu ka tila is a hub of tibbetian market.The nearest metro station is vishwa vidyala.It is also a bus stand and buses for Dharmshala starts from here.Many Tibbetian hotels are here.

Name: Radhika
Title: Went to Ama Cafe.
Review: This place is quite famous for lapping food and Ama Cafe. I visited with my friend, and tried AMA CAFE which is really very good in terms of food. There is a great staff and hygiene the provide mud cake is my favourite from this place. 5 cheez pizza was quite ok a Virgin Mojito was also nice.

Name: Sounak Poddar
Title: Tibetian Culture
Review: One of the best places to visit in Delhi, if one is momo and Tibetian food lover then this place is your paradise. one can also get different attire to buy from these vendors. so one must visit this place. me and my friends love roaming around here as we are a great fan of all the Tibetian food and also because we are foodie.

Name: Lovedeep_06
Title: Gurdwara Majnu Ka Tilla
Review: This Gurdwara Saheb is built on the bank of Yamuna River. Last Sunday, i went to this place with my family, very early in the morning. It was really a great experience as Kirtan was going on and there was peace all around. Old "Gutka Saheb & Guru Granth Saheb are creamated (burnt) here. Some people come here with the ashes of the dead ones to throw them in the running water of Yamuna.

Name: chinmoy c
Title: Trip to Little Tibet in the heart of Delhi
Review: It was visit filled with fun and seeing exotic things in Majnu ka Tila. Which is a small refugee colony for Tibetians in Delhi. Inhabited for a few decades now it is home to these people. Tibetians are the most peace loving people in the world. The place exudes a charm of its own with lots of restaurants serving tasty Tibetian food even Korean food. Shops fulk of artefacts, Tibetian jewellery, food ingredients for Tibetian cuisine are plenty here.  Mostly visitors are college teens and shops selling garments and shoes to their taste are here.Overall it was a lovely experience and to top it all food was great.God bless Tibet.

Name: charlessthomson
Title: Little piece of traditional Tibetan heaven
Review: This is probably the most under rated tourist destination in Delhi.  Over the years the Indian Tibetan community has learnt to become very innovative and this colony has become a cluster of amazing fusion restaurants from Asia but mainly Tibetan.  You can easily spend the whole day here.  Lots of varieties of shop and three buddhist temples too. Given its proximity to Delhi universities lots of students visit here and there is a thriving cafe culture.  Not sure what to eat then I recommend finding either a Tibetan or Bhutanese or Nepali thali.  In the summer another great thing too is because all the building are three storey with narrow pathways you can avoid the sun for most of the day too.  Definitely a unique and wonderful destination.

Name: Ms.sumi
Title: For the love of Thukpa and trinketsüòÄ
Review: Get down from Vidhan sabha metro station pronto and get moving. Autorickshaw "bhaiyajis"will be standing just at the exit gate waiting for you üòÅ,get along one auto it just takes 10Rs to take you to your destination. There is this flyover bridge you need to cross that before you get one step  closer to your mini Tibet. Yes go on an empty stomach and slurp your way away with a large bowl of chicken, pork and buff Thukpa(i personally love Lhasa restaurant, it's not fancy at all so for person who prefers comfort can hit lhasa restaurant).Get amazing trinkets at amazingly cheap price, come across maroon clad robe monks in cool sneakers, the famous Lhaping just 10cm away as soon as you enter the market, get your hands on hot steamed tingmo, visit Buddhist temple, fashionable clothes on every showroom corner...list goes onP.S(not I love you üòÅjust to remind you to try the Rabbit toffee believe me you can even eat the wrapper it's surprisingly tasty)

Name: scs-953
Title: Unique experience! Struggling to retain its identity.
Review: Manju ka Tilla , a small settlement for Tibetans is a very popular place to buy Tibetan handicrafts and eat simple and sumptuous meal. Over the years it‚Äôs become very very popular with college students and foreigners who visit the place to buy Tibetan handcrafts etc Like many other places , it‚Äôs slowly becoming too modern and is beginning to lose its Old world charm. It‚Äôs a welcome change to see some new coffee shops offering juices and good coffee. But one hopes that common sense would prevail and MT as it‚Äôs called would retain its charm. But it‚Äôs certainly worth a visit. Easily accessible by metro and then a shared e rickshaw.

Name: George P
Title: A bittersweet visit
Review: After a maniacally mad taxi ride we entered this tiny Tibetan enclave in the centre of Delhi.There are marvellous shops selling Tibetan handcrafts, a delicious lunch was ridiculously cheap ... around ¬£3 for us both.The Buddhist temple,  monks and prayer wheels give a sense of what a village in Tibet might be like.The sadness lies in visiting displaced people far away from the mountains and valleys of their homeland. ....

Name: Chris S
Title: Nice place
Review: Very nice place to visit. Beautiful thinks you can see and food is very nice you can find lot of Korean restaurants also.

Name: Ashit
Title: Quaint living space that oozes a tradition that is becoming extinct.
Review: With little shops that sell all kinds of products, small eating joints, narrow snake like corridors, this place oozes Tibetan character. Mostly women manage the shops, and the youth are out working elsewhere in the city. Abound with dogs and puppies, the sensitive and caring nature of the people comes through in the manner each one of the dogs is openly friendly (obviously having seen only love from humans around).

Name: garychopel
Title: Momo land.. heavenly.
Review: New Aruna Nagar better known as MT for majnu ka tilla is a heaven for anyone interested in Tibetan food and similar.. wongden house, TeeDees, Himalayan house, u name it and every restaurant belts some of the best dishes that will make u want more..

Name: Diptendra Prasad
Title: Great and authentic Tibetan food is available here
Review: If you want to taste great Tibetan food and want it economically priced visit the Tibetan settlement here. One of my favourite restaurant here is Dolma House. The momos are the most delicious I ever had here. They serve all varieties of momo, from mutton, buff, chicken. Fried rice and Thukpas are also great here.

Name: Naseem p
Title: Budhist lifestyle
Review: The place is a colony of authentic Buddhist beilievers came from Tibet few years back. U can experience their different lifestyle there. The most important thing is to experience Tibetan cuisines and place is so good for shopping, unlike other markets in Delhi u get branded (I think so) things here at reasonable price. It's also closer to signature bridge

Name: sengasen
Title: Hangout
Review: It's a Tibetan market... Very good for shopping and awesome varieties of food.. Specially seafood, price is very reasonable. Best place for gruop of 5/6 friends, or even family. Place is crowded but Worth it...

Name: nonsense193
Title: Unique
Review: Great shopping for things from Tibet. A very unique area with large and small prayer wheels that you can turn to make blessings. Places to eat.

Name: ashishshandilya
Title: Great porbabikity of thefts.
Review: Please take utmost care of your belongings. Things like chain snatching, bag snatching, mobile snatching is very very common. Be careful even while sitting in e-rikshaw.Thanks

Name: Hardial_13
Title: Great To Visit
Review: Majnu ka Tilla is a great place for Tibetan food and shopping. This is located near to the main highway.

Name: Bhingari
Title: hidden world in the middle of north delhi
Review: Interesting Tibetan colony with winding narrow lanes. A hidden wold inside the gate. Plenty restaurants serving tibetan food. We went to Tee Dee. Fabulous food. Also have leather goods stores, ethnic wear stores, and the temple of course.

Name: Daydream18620127370
Title: Good visit
Review: Momos were good here. We had to change a bus here and found the place on trip advisor. Do visit if you want to see a mini Tibet in Delhi

Name: Ashaa78
Title: Great place for Tibetian food and shopping
Review: This Tibetian colony is a good hangout place to eat good Tibetian food (restaurant and road-side) and has multiple places to shop for. One must explore this place when they visit Delhi.

Name: MoushumiBhattacharya
Title: Tibetan Colony and a foodies paradise!
Review: A settlement colony of Tibet refugees in North Delhi just a few kilometres from ISBT is a heaven for Thukpa and momo lovers. This colony gives us a feeling of Tibetan paradise with every alternate shop dishing out the variations of momo, rhukpa and many other delicacies from their homeland.

Name: Udit_007
Title: Great place to hangout
Review: This place is colony of Tibetians in Delhi. It is full of shops with handicrafts, ayurvedic and organics stuffs, very cheap and excellent quality. This palce also offers great cafes and restaurants especially tibetian and korean. Don't expect any bar or pubs. No alcohol in this area.

Name: Jalal Iqbal
Title: good place to see tibeet culture
Review: an hour drive from delhi. a good place to see Tibetan culture, ppl and food. u can see many Tibetan people living here and their houses and shops.can visit to have some taste of tibet if u have time.

Name: Ashish S
Title: Great visit
Review: It was worth visiting this place with friends and family members.We enjoyed our time spent over there.

Name: Amolak Rattan K
Title: Famous Gurudwara and Tibetan Market
Review: Historically this place is revered because First Sikh Guru Nanak Devji had stayed here in the early part of sixteenth century . A beautiful Gurudwara now attracts thousands of devotees every day . Governor Amolak Rattan Kohli

Name: 9708372852a
Title: Bus stop of many tourists places
Review: We had to went there to take the bus for Manali. Many street food were there. I love to eat momoes of Majnu ka tilla. Place is also good for shoping.

Name: hoff1205
Title: Known as the Tibet Colony
Review: It has lots of Tibeten style restaurants and lots of shops selling gifts from the Tibet region too.  It's a nice place but it could do with a little face lift, but it is worth a visit, and remember the restaurants don't open until midday and most of the shops won't open until 10:30-11:00 am.

Name: shefali singh
Title: Best kept secret in Delhi
Review: If you're bored with cliched cafes and bar in Delhi and wanna experience something new. Then friends Majnu ka Tilla is a perfect place for you. This Tibetan monastery has a lot to offer from hill-based cafes to mini Tibet market. Both summers and winters are good to explore.

Name: FarrellX
Title: Little Tibet in Delhi
Review: Was an interesting stop while waiting for the bus to Dharamshala - it's a little Tibetan refuge and reminds me a lot of Lhasa. Decent coffee and cafes as well, I didn't have the chance to try the food though.

Name: noopur s
Title: great place to feel a bit of tibetan culture
Review: can find great tibetan collection here, with touch of their local culture. some different sort of market, and food at a very reasonable prices.

Name: nik_0107
Title: Little Tibet
Review: Close to university campus, the place houses Tibiten refugees wihch have done great wonders to this place. A really good place to have a short walk coupled with a dinner from one of the great and economical restaurants.

Name: NanditaAbraham
Title: Fabulous experience
Review: great ambience and feel of being in a special part of Delhi. So close to the main road but a true hideawayrelaxed atmosphere and good browsing and shoppingSuper food both Tibetan restaurants and Cafe Oma. Laffing is to die for!

Name: Vikas G
Title: Very famous for the tibetian market
Review: I use to visit this place due to the presence of famous tibetian market.. the fashion street offers some great clothing at very low prices.. highly recommended

Name: Abhishek Gupta
Title: Amazing Ambience- a place with soulful vibes
Review: Majnu ka tilla is a feel of a different peace, hilly-like market regions, place to worship in this hectic delhi life. Majnu ka tilla is all about food, market, some antique products. Must visit

Name: John B
Title: A bit of Tibet in Delhi
Review: This may not be to everyone's taste as a place to stay, although you'll find great deals on hotels and restaurants, but it's a fascinating place to visit. Majnu ka Tilla (officially called New Aruna Nagar Colony, Chungtown, and Samyeling) is home to the Tibetan community in New Delhi, not too far from the Red Fort. There are shops, stores, restaurants and temples in what is essentially a small town of about 2,500 people.Sure, the nearby park is a bit messy and the Yamuna River is in need of cleaning up, but even so, it's worth a visit to get away from the bustle of Delhi and do a little meditation, visit the Sakya College, pick up some thangkas, and enjoy a treat and some coffee at Ama Cafe.

Name: Marty C
Title: Great restbite from the madness of delhi
Review: I arrived back in delhi for the second time after a trip to nepal. I wasn't really looking forward to the business  and hassle of delhi. That's when I came across majnu ka tilla thanks to lonely planet.This place really felt like a different world amongst delhi, a lot more laid back, lots of guest houses, and places to eat, and more value for your money. People here were really friendly, so  much so it's sparked an interest for me in all things Tibetan

Name: Krittika M
Title: A Hidden Gem
Review: Another detailed review coming up!As a resident of Delhi, I have travelled to Majnu ka Tila several times and wanted to add a review of the place as a local. Aruna Colony, popularly known as Majnu ka Tila is a refugee colony for Tibetans in exile. As you would wander along in the colony, you would come across several portraits of the Holy Dalai Lama and merchandise with the quotes Free Tibet. That is because this colony was started as a camp for people who fled Tibet during the 1960's.The primarily attractions of the area is it's main square, i.e. Gumpa Square and the restaurants that serve authentic Tibetan, Nepali and Korean food. From an architectural point of view, the most interesting place is the Gumpa square which has two monasteries and two temples. This is the primary gathering point for locals and as you walk through the square, you would often come across the elderly sitting and talking and children playing around. While in the square, please don't forget to eat 'LA-PHING'. It's a tibetan snack made out of flour, tofu, garlic and spices and is quite delicious. It is served by locals sitting outside the monastery and is a definite recommendation to anyone visiting MKT.While moving around in the colony, there isn't much to see. Most of the colony has small, cramped houses built one over each other. Every few houses you come across stores selling stationary, clothes, boots etc., but a lot of stuff is imported from Nepal and isn't overtly cheap too. There are also several shops that sell day to day snacks etc, which are worth a visit if you know the culture.Definitely visit this place if you're looking to try something new for your next weekend plans. Would recommend to travelers looking to eat authentic tibetan food, but might not be worth all the extra travel, especially if you're staying in South Delhi.Places to See : Gumpa Square, Tibetan MarketThings to Do: Shopping, Eating

Name: Shantanu K
Title: TIBETAN REFUGEE COLONY
Review: Perfect place in delhi to spend the evening, night, day and even week. It has lots of hotels you can check into and the experience is one you will not find anywhere else in delhi.Majnu ka tilla or rather Tibetan refugee colony is more like a mini tibet with at least 50 cafes serving authentic tibetan, north east indian, korean, and thai food. You can also find mainstream cafes here. Local delhi people look like tourist here.Lafing, a tibetan snack is a must try and the stalls are unmissable in the main square.Cafes to try are ama cafe, yamuna cafe, kham cafe.For korean cuisine go to kori's. For tibetan dolma or Tee dee. For nepali ama thakali is the best in entire delhi.Also you can visit the yamuna bank behind the market for a peaceful evening and go shopping in its many shops and stalls through its narrow roads.

Name: rahulp711
Title: Favorite place for Momo's
Review: This is one place which i frequent for Momos and other Tibetan food. This is a Tibetan settlement with lot of restaurants providing authentic Tibetan food. I usually visit Dolma house which is my favorite.- Also light on pocket.

Name: Alex B
Title: Tibetan enqlave, very quite and authentic
Review: Great place both to escape rush of chaotic Delhi and embrace Tibetan atmosphere. Also browsing nature streets of Majnu ka tilla reminds of Walled City in Hong Kong, not for claustrophobic people ))

Name: Kuljyoti Dhingra
Title: Most favorite place in Delhi
Review: My sole purpose to visit Majnu Ka Tila is to escape from the commotion of Delhi into tranquility of the Tibetan Colony. The moment you enter Majnu ka Tila you'll find Gurudwara which is a holy place for the sikhs. Moving further into the Tibetan colony you'll come across Tibetan monasteries. This place is located in Delhi but is subtly different from Delhi. Not only an calming experience but this place also has no dearth of food and shopping options. You'll find places like Tee Dee, AMA Restaurant, Dolma House, etc. serving authentic Tibetan food in the comfort of Delhi. Further, if you are hunting for good quality boots, then nothing can be better than this market. I simply love going to this place.

Name: Travel_BaBa
Title: A unique place within the crazy life of Delhi . a true tibetan experience
Review: Located right on the GT road, not very far from the ISBT(new Delhi), this is a place where you can enjoy the tibetan culture. there's a monastery and the narrow alleys inside has shops selling tibetan stuff.If you want to enjoy the traditional tibetan food, there are multiple options to chose from and you will not regret it. the place is unique and it gives an impression that perhaps you are in Tibet .  A must visit if you want to get a taste of the tibetan culture.

Name: Anamika K
Title: One of the best hangout in Delhi
Review: Majnu ka Tila is a Tibetan colony, but a very well maintained hangout place. This is the place in Delhi where being in the very heart of it you can forget conveniently that you're not on Delhi. Amazing cafes and restaurants particularly, there is a fair chance that you might think of going to Dharamsala or mcleodganj after a visit here and so, easy and quick bus are also available from here.

Name: Amrita Gupta
Title: A mini Tibet.
Review: This beautiful place has tiny streets with street hawkers and so many cafes and restaurants. There is a huge square with a monastry kind of thing, where you can find the famous street food Laphing. Do visit here for great authentic Tibetan and Chinese at a very cheap price. Must Visit is Ama Restaurant and Ama Cafe.

Name: Satyendra Garg
Title: Mini Tibet in Delhi.
Review: It is a different world, a mini Tibet, right in Delhi. Having been in Delhi for about 30 years I did not get a chance to see this miniature Tibet right inside the city, though I have been to Tibetan Monatstries all over the country including Leh, Sikkam and Arunachal Pradesh.My work took me to Majnu ka Tilla Tibetan settlement. What I discovered in the process is an amazing world. They have , not one, two Tibetan Temples, one for the Gelug sect and the other for Nyimga sect. They have Settlement Office, dealing with issues of the settlers, they have beautiful market in serpentine lane, beautiful eateries, a Primary school and lots and lots of Tibetan things, including a hospital and medical shop. You find pictures of Dalai Lama everywhere. There are Tibetans living there who came from Tibet way back in 1959 and the Tibetans who have never been to Tibet but want to be there. Altogether a good experience. Those who love things Tibetans, food and other things will find it a rewarding experience.

Name: Ira1971
Title: For a change
Review: It‚Äôs quiet and peaceful but the alleys are dark and damp. I didn‚Äôt stay very long. I visited the temple and a little park with tibetan flags. It‚Äôs not the place where I would stay but for a change it‚Äôs something different.

Name: Kumar S
Title: Majnu Ka Tilla
Review: An interesting place to visit, sort of mini Tibet inside Delhi. 10 min walk from nearest metro station Vishwavidyalaya.

Name: lamayume
Title: Buddhist place
Review: A mini tibet in Delhi... u will get tibetian and Nepali in this place.,, there is a monastery as well with tibetian culture all around.. I stayed there for 3 days as u can get many hotels in cheap price.. as Nepali I felt very comfortable there because lots of Nepali also live there with tibetian and Nepali restaurants but i was suggested not to go out late coz of drunk people around there and this place is famous for tibetian drinks and it‚Äôs not safe for a girl maybe this is what I already heard about all Delhi so that was fine but overall it‚Äôs quite friendly area

Name: Urvashi Y
Title: Wondeful Place with Delicious Food
Review: This place has always been the best escape for all DU students (of North Campus).Amazing local tibetian food with great ambience. The narrow passages opening to cute little restaurants leave you craving for more once you dine there. Must-Try: Ama ThakaliServes Nepalese cuisine. Price: Rs. 400 for 2 (unlimited quantity)Opens: 11 AM to 10 PM

Name: jinpa p
Title: A place u must visit !!
Review: For all those people who r in Delhi and haven't visit majnu ka tilla yet,,, I want u all to visit it once !! It is a small Tibetan market , but u will find different things to explore there, u will find lots of good and beautiful cafe which will serve u very good drinks and different restaurant will will serve different cuisine !! There are also some different souvenir shops there from which u will get lots of different stuffs to buy ... the whole environment is very wonderful and people there are very friendly and welcoming!!I am sure u all will love it!! What you waiting for now, juz take out sometime and visit there once!!

Name: Khushboo Gupta
Title: Church
Review: We were going to catch bus from majnu ka tila bus stand. There was a nice Church. Place is ok ok lots of food and shops their.

Name: Vipul Agarwal
Title: Shop, eat & stay... ample options for all these needs!!
Review: This market located near Kashmere Gate ISBT is one of the most unexplored hidden gem of Delhi. Though, this is predominated by Tibetans, it's as good a place as any for all your needs. If you want fashionable clothes at moderate price, or a nice cafe-cum-restobar, or may be a small hotel to spend a night, you can get everything here and more than a hundred choices for each!! People don't prefer this only because they feel intimidated by the local community, but hey these are good friendly people and they won't charge you much also!! Do try out for yourself.

Name: Derek E
Title: Peace and quiet at Delhi Tibetan Colony
Review: I can't imagine that the Tibetan Colony in Nth Delhi has changed much in the past year. My stay there was for 2 nights at the Wongdhen House hotel where they served delicious momo, the well known food from Tibet. At the very reasonably priced hotel I had a large terrace with a superb view of the Jamuna river meandering by. I might add here that I think it would be extremely unlucky not to find a room if you just arrive on the off chance.But the best part of it was the peace that even the market did not disturb, where haggling is not necessary in order to buy something, so different from almost every other market in the sub-continent. So to sum up, even though getting to the colony can be a little stressful, it is a perfect place to chill out and recover from the excesses of traveling around India, and experience the peaceful Tibetan culture.

Name: MANEY SAINI
Title: Gurdwara Majnu Ka Tilla
Review: we went in the early morning with me and my brother to worship there on sunday morning and the place is on the main gt road when go to kashmiri gate

Name: Nisha S
Title: Exploring the place
Review: I was born in Delhi but seldom did I ventured out on my own  to explore new places . This place is so surrounded by mixed reviews that I finally decided to  go there and experience it once. So curiosity led me there. I wanted to see Tibetan way of life , people, some glimpses of its culture. Believe me , I was not disappointed. This place is next to the Sikh Gurudwara and it has a Buddhist temple inside. Perfect example of religious tolerance. But entry gate is a real deterrent !  There was filth strewn around and foul smell emanating from it. But,  once inside, there is another world. Well kept shops, cafes and restaurants defy the logic that why the merchant community does not  unite and do something to get the authorities keep hygienic environment ! We dined at The Himalaya Restaurant. Delicious food, Nice interiors, courtious staff and a big screen to watch the sports events ,coupled with pocket friendly menu with so much variety . What else can you ask for to have good time? Then outside, I bought a pair of stylish Canvas shoes for myself which was a real bargain. I really had a great time with my Son equally impressed by the place. He is young is. In his 20 birth year and I think it is an affordable and happening place with a little dose of history for young people to spend some time and have fun.

Name: aastha98
Title: Nothing much as in general to do
Review: The place is damp and dark.The nearest metro is vidhan sabha . some people are under the influence of intoxication and rome  about .Shopping are comparatively expensive .Have good Korean food and glimpse of Tibetan culture .

Name: tripsmaker
Title: Walking to Little Tibet
Review: It is a Tibetian settlement in New Aruna Nagar of North Delhi. Originally a person called Majnu lived here, and Guru Nanak once stayed with him after watching his devotion to God. Sikh army commander Baghel Singh built Majnu Ka Tilla Gurdwara, which one of the oldest Sikh shrines in New Delhi. In 1960 Tibetian refugees settled down, after Government of India alloted land for them. It is also known as little Tibet. There is a small monastery and a Buddhist temple, Plus lots of restaurants, cafes, small shops,  curio shops. This place is very popular with national and international tourist in Delhi.

Name: Nikhil P
Title: Must try
Review: Located near North Campus of Delhi University, this is a place occupied by Tibetian refugees. It has narrow bylanes with shops offering traditional tibetian style jewellery, art and snacks . There  are Buddhist temple as well as a gurudwara situated in Majnu ka tila showcasing the religious tolerance of India which otherwise remains oblivion to Indian news channels . Anyway, the food choices are mind boggling over here so I settled for traditional ones like momos. It‚Äôs a good place to spendfew hours if you are new to Delhi and want to explore Buddhist and Tibetian culture .

Name: Rakesh s
Title: Lover point
Review: It is the sign of love. People from all over the country comes to visit this place. It is very awesome place.

Name: Shivani Rastogi
Title: mini tibet in delhi - shop, hop, eat, repeat!!!
Review: A walk on the Buddhist side of life: Delhi‚Äôs Mini TibetPicture this: winding alleys, cool breeze blowing in your face, faint echoes of Dalai Lama‚Äôs preaching, graceful Tibetan ladies in their traditional attire selling momos in the courtyard, vibrant colours, unusual smells, the serene soft music made by the prayer bells. A smaller, condensed version of Dharamsala‚Ä¶while it may be a world not many will relate to, it does not fail to enchant!Delhi is a goldmine for history buffs, and I love it when some of our favourite spots come with a quaint bit of history attached to them. Majnu Ka Tila, also known as Delhi‚Äôs mini-Tibet, is one such place. It opens up to you a small world so splendid and exquisite that you just don‚Äôt want to leave. HistoryIf lores are to be believed, this North Delhi area is named after a Sufi mystic, a ferryman who rowed people across the Yamuna as a service to god. He became so wrapped up in spiritual musings that people began to call him Majnu, after the legendary lover driven to near insanity. The locality is also set atop a hillock, thus the tila in the name makes sense as well. Majnu Ka Tila also has a Gurudwara, which is one of the oldest extant Sikh shrines in the city and was named after him. Around 1960, after the Tibetan uprising, refugees set up camp in this area and since then it has become the go-to place for all things Tibetan. Along with the Gurudwara, there is also a Buddhist monastery in the bylanes and the general vibe is one of tranquillity.The EntranceSo off we went, one sunny afternoon, to peruse the mysteries of Majnu ka Tilla, which turns out to be a stone‚Äôs throw from Delhi University‚Äôs North Campus and is easily reached by the Delhi Metro. A Buddhist-style gate stands amid grey, three-storey structures, packed close together. Tall buildings on either side make the narrow alley so dark it‚Äôs as if the sun never makes it here. I feel we‚Äôve stepped into a different world, far removed from the urban chaos of Delhi. Shops on either side sell only exotic Tibetan jewellery, Buddhist artefacts and crockery. Ahead, the alley opens into a bright courtyard facing the monastery.As we walk towards the monastery, the alleys open out to a little space in front of a red and yellow building with decorated pillars and flags flying atop it. It also has the dharmachakra between two deers. This building is the office of the cultural centre and the monastery stands to its left ‚Äì a structure similarly designed with the same symbols, albeit taller. Like a little town square, the open space in front of the monastery and the cultual centre is filled with people. There are snack counters, vegetable vendors mingling with people who have come to offer prayers at the monastery or simply sitting around.What struck me when we reached the colony was that there were  vibrant prayer flags hanging from every nook and corner of these narrow by-lanes, seemingly inviting us on a mystical journey. Each flag has a different texture and its own story. Five elements of nature ‚Äì land, water, air, fire and sky merge in these flags. Powered by sacred mantras, they purify the air wherever they are hung as the wind spreads the positive energies in the atmosphere.The Foodie TrailWe decided to sample local Tibetan food and try a delicious snack locally known as ‚ÄòLaphing‚Äô which the locals almost pronounced as ‚Äòlaughing‚Äô. Laphing is originally a Northern Chinese cuisine known as Liangfen, which literally translates to cold noodle. This dish travelled to Nepal with Tibetan and Chinese people who later settled in Boudha.It is basically, potato starch and mung bean combined together to form dry gelatinous  pan cakes, which are rolled and cut into bite-size pieces, and are enclosed with minced soya bean and garlic vinegar, soya sauce, sesame oil and red chilli sauce creates a spectacular cold snack. Laphing can be consumed dry or with cold soup. We tried the dried version as a starter and then ordered for Laphing soup. It is potato starch and mung-bean-jelly noodles, (just like the dry version, just cut in shape of flat noodles) heaped w/chillies, chilli oil, soy sauce, scallions & mouth-tingling Sichuan peppercorns. It's an interesting, delightful dish--spicy, cold & slippery. Watch out for the heat from the chillies, it‚Äôs strong yet addictive. Total cost Rs. 110.Coming to Majnu ka tila and not eating momos would be a sin, so we headed to Tee Dee, which is at a few minutes distance from the Laphing Counter. Tee Dee at Majnu Ka Tila is an authentic Tibetan affair. Although Tee Dee is a small place, it definitely stands out for its authentic home cooked food. The restaurant serves Tibetan and Chinese food. The place can comfortably accommodate over 40 people and has a bright and sunny feel to it. It is done up in a traditional Buddhist manner with loads of laughing Buddhas and dragons. Though their menu comprised of a variety of Chinese and Tibetan offerings, but we settled for a portion of their steamed Chicken momos as well as Mutton momos. And to wash it all down, their famous Apple Beer was the preference. The flour coating of the momos was just apt, not too thick to obstruct the flavour. The chicken and lamb mince was soft and juicy and packed full of flavour. I would have liked a little more filling to make them the best momos. The Apple Beer, was non-alcoholic and different from the usual fruit beer, it was the perfect accompaniment to all the piping hot delicious dimsums. Total cost was just Rs. 300.We loved exploring the bylanes and doing some shopping here and there. After browsing for a while and promising to be back again for more shopping, we headed to our next destination, which was located at the end of the lane, the famous Ama Restaurant. Located few minutes of walk away from Rigo Restaurant, the Ama Restaurant is another popular Himalayan Cuisine restaurant in the area. The place is well-known for its authentic Tibetan cuisine. The food here tastes exactly like home cooked food. Give Ama a try once. You will not be disappointed. Here we ordered Lemon Chicken (soft), Chicken in Butter Chilly Garlic Sauce and to polish them off we had their Egg Fried Rice along with Tingmo. The Lemon Chicken was just nothing like I have had before. Tender morsel of chicken tossed in a very thick lemon sauce, topped with bell peppers, green beans etc. the lemon sauce had a very pronounced citric taste of lemon and this tinge was a welcoming surprise for our palate. Chicken in butter chilly garlic sauce was another hit, the chicken was juicy and soft and the white cream base butter gravy flavoured with ample garlic to which diced bell peppers were added, was just finger licking good. The egg fried rice were delicious as well. Tingmo is a steamed fermented bread, unlike all other breads I‚Äôve tried before. But it was love at the first bite! It has a unique taste of its own, and went perfectly with the two dishes. Total damage for such delectable food was merely Rs. 550.Though we were almost full by then, but we wanted to venture more and try Korean cuisine and so we headed to this beautifully done up caf√©/restro called Kori‚Äôs. Little did we know that going to this place would turn out be the worst decision ever. So for the Korean part of it we ordered their Bulgogi Bibimbap, and to keep things balanced we ordered their Chocolate Pancakes along with Ice Caf√© Latte. The Ice Caf√© Latte was more like warm, diluted hot chocolate gone bad, it was just average. The pancakes were a total shocker, rectangle shaped extremely undercooked something, (as they certainly were not pancakes, either by looks, ingredients or taste) served with two tiny cups filled with chocolate sauce and nutella each were apparently their chocolate pancakes. We had high hopes from their Bulgogi Bibimbap. The word literally means ‚Äúmixed rice‚Äù. It is served as a bowl of warm Korean sticky rice topped with namul (saut√©ed and seasoned vegetables, which unfortunately in this case was just shredded cabbage) and gochujang (chilli pepper paste), soy sauce, again here the soy was missing and the chilli paste was very less in quantity. A fried egg and sliced bulgogi (beef/buff) are added on top. The egg and the buff slices were very dry and chewy. The entire experience was horrendous and we left everything. I do not recommend this place at all. The total cost for this pathetic experience came down to Rs. 500.Though we were stuffed by now, but just because we had a very foul taste teasing our palate, we decided to head to one last stop for the day, The Coffee House, which is located in the basement of Kham Gangdrug Complex. It‚Äôs a cute little caf√© with a vibrant funky feel to it. we tried their famous Mud Cake. A warm huge square of a piece of this deliciousness was the perfect choice. The chocolate cake was very light, airy and had a crumbly texture. The delicious cake was topped with a shiny delectable chocolate ganache. It was just pure bliss. The only thing, I would have obviously liked more ganache as compare to the volume of the cake. Price was this goodness, Rs. 75.The veritable ‚ÄòMini Tibet‚Äô is indeed what it claims to be: a small sample of Tibet. It showcases a convincing replica of authentic Tibetan food, culture and tradition.

Name: Bruce R
Title: Great District in Delhi
Review: Laid back vib on this busy Tibetan refuge in North Delhi. Worth a night or two.  Great cafes and guest houses line the small alleyways and streets chocked full of vendors.

Name: massimo g
Title: wonderful escape from crowded Delhi
Review: This pleasant and joyful area is just opposite Mother Teresa Missionaires of Charity house.It's a little village developed around a tiny street full of shops, cafes and restaurant. Friendly people all from Tibet You can have a coffee e meet great people, tibetan monks and other stranger that make you feel like at home.Very few people know the existence of this little Tibetan enclave but I do believe it's one or, probably, the best places to visit in Delhi.

Name: migmarl
Title: Liesure
Review: Super good food their with lovely people ... thank you trip advisor for the suggestion app for everyone to know exactly which is worth to stay or eat....

Name: Joe
Title: Peace in the middle of Delhi
Review: This is great place to relax if you need to get away from some of the busyness of Delhi! It is very friendly and there are lots of nice cafes, shops and guesthouses. It is also easy to get to via the metro! Take the yellow line north and get off at vidhan sabha and then it is just a short auto ride.

Name: divechka
Title: They call it Little New York
Review: Anyone wanting to witness a unique cultural situation - take time to enjoy this Tibetan community! We spent about 7 nights in total here through December and January . There are wonderful western cafes and restaurants, wholesale jewellers, traditional vendors, etc. Everything you want can be found here!The hotels are often overbooked - so arriving late night mean forfeiting a room. Be careful! The streets are super windy and there is so much to take in. I was able to bring back some lovely Buddhist practice items as well as more traditional gifts such as yak wool shawls (for men and women!).

Name: travel6264
Title: Tibetan  colony
Review: Went there to see the Buddhist temple. Was disappointed to see how small it is. .Did not visit the inside as it was closed for lunch, from noon to 2pm! Rest of the colony is ok, lots of shops, some better than others. Not sure I would recommend,  there is so much to see in Delhi before this part of town

Name: Charline091
Title: Small alleys ways with great attraction
Review: This is a Tibetan colony in North Delhi. Small alley ways but has so much to offer. handicrafts, shops, restaurant of Tibetan and chinese food and many more. Not very expensive!! you should visit during a visit of Delhi

Name: Srishti J
Title: Little Tibet tucked away in Delhi
Review: I recently went to Majnu ka Teela in North Delhi. It is primarily a Tibet refugee camp, where people's first language is still Tibetan. You can see monks pass by, and the monastery. So if you want to taste authentic north- eastern food, this is the place for you. We went to Rigo's for tibetan food.It was pretty amazing. We also tried the street food. So if you visit this place eating "Laffing" is a must. The place also has cafes serving Naga cuisine. You can also buy spices that are used in north-eastern cuisine here. Other than that, you have variety of gift shops that sell amazing tibetan knick-knacks- including clothing and decor. And everything here is very easy on the pocket.So to sum up, if you are visiting Delhi and want to experience something entirely different than the Delhi you know, then this is the place for you.P.S- please do not order your regular chinese food at the restaurants here. Try something new, it will definitely do you good!

Name: Kapil Vijan
Title: Famous for Tibetan culture, Gurudwara and outstation bus stoppage
Review: There are primarily 3 things famous about Majnu ka Tilla i.e.1) The Gurudwara2) Tibetan food and culture3) Outstation bus stoppage especially for buses travelling to North India

Name: Shareen Laskar
Title: Tibetian food!
Review: Wants to have Tibetan food while in New Delhi you must go to Majnu Ka Tilla. You'll find numerous Tibetian restaurant which offers all Tibetan delicacies.

Name: Dishaa S
Title: an unexplored gem
Review: not very often visited by tourists, this is Tibetan culture hub where one can savor a flavour of everything tibetan be it food, artifacts, lifestyle etc.

Name: Trista
Title: Confusing alley, relaxing athmosphere
Review: Nice place in Delhi.  For female solo traveller, I kind of feel hesitant to get into the complex since I arrived at night.  It is kind of secluded area with confusing narrow alleys. But once you get there, it is quite relax and feel safe.  Certainly different compared with all traffic and busy road in other Delhi area.It gives the same vibe of Thamel St. in Nepal though, only less crowded.  If you miss Nepali and Tibetan food, it is a great place :)

Name: JessicaField_
Title: Tibetan culture tucked away in the North of Delhi
Review: I took my students here for an afternoon trip to explore the area and it was a really interesting and enjoyable experience. Lots of nooks and crannies to explore in the colony, and the area has a different feel to the rest of the city. Lots of delicious food joints and small shops selling all sorts, including Tibetan artesanial goods. Great little market on the front as you enter. And pay attention to the interesting signs and messages on the wall - which not only offer good advice for healthy living but refer to the political context that has created this settlement in the first place.

Name: Roderick J
Title: Nice and peaceful üñí
Review: Nice place to be in Delhi. Tibetan people are very relaxed. When you step into this neighbourhood it's like another world compared to Delhi. Not so much beggars like Delhi. Good restaurants and small guesthouses/ hotels. We did enjoy it.

Name: PreetKSingh
Title: nice visit
Review: good place to visit.. usually gone there only for my bus haults fro amritsar to delhi.. the place isquiet eat and clean and the overall atmosphere is also good...

Name: lotusdiamond
Title: Feel of North east!!!
Review: This place is situated very near to ISBT Bus terminal. People from Tibet have settled here and doing small business of selling clothes etc. You will feel as if you are in North east.

Name: Uttamthapa
Title: What a Place!!
Review: I would like to rate this place as best place for a northeastern Indian..Loved the environment, the area ..when u visit her you are one step closer to your Northeast Home..You find anything you want from Northeast..Must visit

Name: Coolbuddy83
Title: All in One
Review: This is a all in one place. You can find everything here hotel, clothes, good authentic eating joints. Must visit to experience different culture.

Name: yukimori321
Title: hotel, food, etc review
Review: This place is a small tibetan community in the heart of the indian city, The hotels are nice and cheap. We can get variety for tibetan food as well as the indian cuisine. Though it is quite faraway from the city, i liked the location and the community living there.

Name: enigmatic1989
Title: Affordable hotels.. Good food.. Fashionable clothes.. What else do you need??
Review: This is the place where you can live eat and shop. There are a lot of good hotels here on different price range and since it is located in the centre of Delhi, you can easily travel to any place from here. Food is also amazing as Majnu Ka Tila is known for its mouth-watering Tibetan food all over India. Also, here you can find many small-n-big shops of garments, artificial jewellery and Buddhist statues to place in your homes. Though, you might have to ask the place as it is in the by lanes of Ring Road near ISBT (Kashmere Gate). The place looks like mini-Tibet with the crowd of it, but trust me it's Indian from soul.

Name: bindu2016
Title: Monasteries
Review: you will find monasteries. lovely clothes, shoes and nice eating joints.  you will love the aura spread out there.

Name: ST_INDIA
Title: Old Monument ... But little hosh-posh
Review: Its a very old monument in Delhi's outer ring road. Not very big still is maintained by govt. The place is little hosh-posh and nothing very significant to watch out for.

Name: neerajdesign
Title: Mini tibet
Review: The narrow lanes of Majnu¬†Ka¬†Tila, a small¬†colony near Kashmere Gate, hide many Tibetan marvels ‚Äì¬†authentic cuisine, colourful traditions and some of the kindest people you will ever meet.It is often surprising for most travel enthusiasts to discover that while they have been off exploring distant places in search of a piece of Tibet, there are gems at their doorstep they haven‚Äôt a clue about. This place houses a world of its own. Since the 1960s, Tibetans have settled down in MKT, as it is locally known, and have built hotels, shops, monasteries and their entire lives here.The unique nomenclatureThis place is named after a ferryman who rowed people across the Yamuna as a service to god. He became so wrapped up in spiritual musings that people began to call him Majnu, after the legendary lover. The gurudwara built here was named after him.

Name: thecommoner
Title: Must visit!
Review: Must visit for the lovely food.  Do try the momos at Ama Rabsel house,  Noodles at Dolma house.  Also a great place for coffee shops which serve great desserts and coffee at very reasonable rate.

Name: joanncmb1
Title: A cheap, safe and exotic locality
Review: Moment you enter Majnu ka Tila, you feel like Alice in Wonderland. You feel as if you have left Delhi behind and entered some exotic land. Tibetans are straight,honest people. The shops are like any other Tibetan shop you see in North India. The hotels and lodges, have good , decent accomodation for very reasonable price. The food in the restaurants are exotic and reasonably priced. The Gompas in the heart of the  settlement have their unique charm.

Name: tanuja t
Title: Bus point for himanchal
Review: Various operators start their buses from majnu ka tila, the place is crowded. Check there for himanchal buses.

Name: ShivangiReviews
Title: An interesting community!
Review: I've always wanted to visit Majnu Ka Tilla for interesting treats. This place is certainly unique. I felt like I had been transported to a small village in Tibet. It was a very interesting experience.I would certainly recommend a visit if you are up for something inyeresting.

Name: Zelpi
Title: Tibet through alleys
Review: The Tibetan colony is a fascinating place in which you can find a different kind of humanity from the one you meet in Delhi. Every alley is full of people and shops along with two beautiful stupas. Visit it to find amazing handcrafts and food

Name: Elite_traveler_927
Title: Tebetan Experience
Review: Get here for a tibetan experience in terms of people, and food. Its got a market for shopping loving people to bargain. The food is nothing extra ordinary but typical tibetan.

Name: Ruby S
Title: The Little Tibet of Delhi, a bit expensive though.
Review: Majnu ka tilla is an appropriate place for shopping and indulging in authentic Tibetan cuisines. As soon as you enter the main lane and walk for a while you will reach a courtyard which has a temple. The temple has quintessential Tibetan look and feel, it reminded me of my visit to the Dalai Lama temple in Mcleodganj. If you are lucky you might get to see them performing their prayer rituals as well.Majnu ka tilla is a great place to shop unique items and junk jewellery. They have road side shops as well as proper stores where you can purchase typical Tibetan stuff for your home.Though it a street market but it is not inexpensive. The uniqueness of items comes with pretty good prices. Highlights for me were prayer wheels, dream catchers, prayer flags, masks, idols of Tibetan deities and solid perfumes. They had some unique shoe collection as well. Majnu ka Tilla houses many restaurants which serve authentic Tibetan food which mainly includes dimsums and thukpa. We ate at the Asian Kitchen and it was an okay experience. Later we got to know that Rigo is great place to eat but it was too late then as we had eaten already. After shopping and eating we decided to head back. It was a different experience and I quite liked it. I might not go back there again unless I have a purpose, but if you haven‚Äôt been there even once then it is worth a visit.

Name: Tenzin J
Title: Wonderful stay at Gyalthang House
Review: Stayed here for two nights and the customer service is flawless. The staff really can't do enough for you. As an experienced lone female traveler I would recommend this place for comfort and friendliness.  Room service for food goes up until 10 o'clock each night. For those familiar with India you know it's great to stay on a budget, but even being a little more expensive than usual at 700 rupee - this place is well worth every penny and I highly recommend it.

Name: Anjali J
Title: Very Expensive...Though a lot of variety...
Review: The place was very expensive as compared to other markets...Though they had exclusive stuff and unique antique jewelry but i found that expensive...The buddhist temple on the main chowk was awesome however...!!

Name: Andi D
Title: Best place to stay in Delhi
Review: It is calm, the tibetan people are (as always) respectfull and passive. You can even enter shops without getting pushed to buy something all the time. I came here when I arrived in Delhi and stayed for 3 nights, had another 3 nights in the middle oft my journey and will stay here again before i fly home. It is clean, calm, relaxing and safe. And you can have good coffee and cake :)

Name: Padmasurana R
Title: From Hinduism to Buddhism
Review: Majnu Ka Tilla is becoming a bit pricey for shopping.  Wonderful if you wish to visit the temple and take food there.  Wong den guest house, one of my favourite places to eat in delhi, also a nice guest house to stay.
